data.source: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) for COVID-19 cases; meteoblue.com for temperature data; indexmundi.com for precipitation; World Bank for economic openness, democracy index, and population density
data.wave_or_subset: Data cover the period 31 Dec 2019 – 3 Apr 2020
data.access_details: All sources are publicly available online; no special access restrictions noted
data.notes: Potential under-reporting in autocratic countries noted by the author; possible multicollinearity among regressors was addressed

method.description: The author compiles cross-country data on COVID-19 cases and several environmental, economic, and social variables and estimates linear regression models to assess associations between these factors and the number of confirmed cases per million people.
steps: Collect cumulative confirmed COVID-19 cases per country from ECDC up to 3 Apr 2020.
Gather yearly average temperature and precipitation data, economic openness (trade as % of GDP), democracy index scores, and population density for each country from the listed secondary sources.
Specify a static linear regression model with COVID-19 cases per million as the dependent variable and five covariates (temperature, precipitation, openness, democracy, population density).
Estimate the model using Ordinary Least Squares (OLS).
Estimate alternative specifications including a lagged dependent variable to check robustness and address autocorrelation.
Diagnose multicollinearity by regressing the lagged dependent variable on the covariates and using residuals in place of the raw lagged term.
Perform heteroscedasticity, normality, and autocorrelation diagnostics.
Interpret coefficients with emphasis on temperature, openness, and democracy index.
method.models: Classical Linear Regression Model (OLS); static model and lagged-dependent-variable model
method.outcome_variable: Total confirmed COVID-19 cases per million population (as of 3 Apr 2020)
method.independent_variables: Yearly average temperature; yearly average precipitation; economic openness (trade % of GDP); democracy index; population density; lagged COVID-19 cases per million (in some specifications)
method.control_variables: Precipitation and population density act as controls when the focus is on temperature, openness, and democracy index

results.summary: Lower average temperature is associated with more COVID-19 cases, while greater economic openness and higher democracy index scores are associated with a higher number of confirmed cases per million. These relationships are statistically significant at the 1 % level across several model specifications. Diagnostic tests reveal heteroscedasticity and non-normal residuals but limited autocorrelation.

numerical_results.outcome_name: COVID-19 cases per million (effect of economic openness)
numerical_results.unit: cases per million per percentage-point of trade-to-GDP

numerical_results.outcome_name: COVID-19 cases per million (effect of democracy index)
numerical_results.unit: cases per million per democracy index point
